title: Can a lien be put on my Mobile home?
question: I own a mobile home that is"NOT" on a permanent foundation. I pay a monthly space rent. I recently became indebted to a large some of money and may soon have a judgment against me. I pay yearly property taxes. Question#1: Is my mobile home real or personal property? question#2: can a lien be put on my mobile home? Question#3: The money is my separate debt . Will my wife also be liable?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Lien,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers:
A mobile home is considered real property. A lien can be put on the title. Your wife could be liable.
If the debt is significant, it may be wise to consult with a bankruptcy attorney.

As the other attorneys have stated, your mobile home is real property and a lien can be recorded against the mobile home. California is a community property state and therefore the mobile phone could very well be community property. As to whether your wife has any liability with your debts, that is an analysis a bankruptcy attorney can do for you. I agree with my colleagues, if you have concerns about your assets at this level, you should see a bankruptcy attorney.

Your mobile home is considered real property for purposes of bankruptcy and is exempt in the amount of approximately $25,000 or up to $175,000 depending on which exemption statute we use. A lien can be put on the property but the creditor will need to get a judgment against you first. Even thought you think it is a separate debt, California is a community property state and as such, your wife may also be liable. Please talk to a bankruptcy attorney for further clarification and to review your options.

Yes a lien can be put on your mobile home. Your wife could be liable. It seems like BK may be a good option for you to rid this debt prior to it becoming a secured debt on your mobile home. Call and speak with an experienced BK attorney .
